captions.text:
Hi, I'm Kathy Santo for
Iams with Howdini.

And today we're going to
discuss the dangers of

allowing puppy biting, the
importance of playing

correctly, and how to stop the
unwanted biting behavior.

It's normal and even cute when
your puppy nibbles and lunges
at your hands.

Since your puppy has been
exposed only other puppies in

the litter who naturally play
with biting and mouthing, it

would make perfect sense why he
would assume that playing

with you wouldn't
be different.

But as puppies' teeth grow and
their bodies become stronger,

what was once cute nibbling
eventually turns into
uncomfortable or even dangerous
rough play and bites.

Since biting is an unacceptable
type of play,

it's important to teach your pup
how to enjoy playing games

with toys instead
of your hand.

Playing is a healthy, natural
activity that helps build the

bond between you
and your puppy.

This also affects your puppy's
trainability--

sitting, waiting, learning
tricks, not pulling on the
leash, even to stop biting.

Before teaching your puppy not
to bite, it's important to

train your puppy to decrease
bite pressure.

Allow your puppy to
begin mouthing and
nibbling at your hand.

When he bites down hard yell
"Ouch!" so he's startled and
stops for a second.

Continue allowing him to mouth
your hand, making sure to

speak up every time he bites
too hard, so your puppy can

learn your threshold for what is
acceptable and what isn't.

Once your puppy understand
your feedback about the

strength of his bite, you can
begin to reduce biting.

The best way to teach your
puppy not to bite is to

redirect him to a toy
or a chew bone.

Simply give your dog a firm no
and replace whatever he was

biting with something he
is allowed to chew.

If your puppy is three to six
months old, there's a good
chance he may be teething.

So he might be trying to reduce
discomfort by chewing.

Try giving him an ice
cube to chew on.

It'll numb his gums and help
alleviate the pain.

My favorite trick is to get
puppies to stop biting is to

exaggerate and pretend they've
injured me, their friend.

By pretending their nip actually
hurt you by putting

your hand away, yelling ouch,
and stop playing, you're

replicating what other litter
mates would do if another
puppy were to cause them pain.

Managing and controlling puppy
biting problems can be a major
challenge for dog lovers.

Puppy biting or nipping starts
out as a bit of fun but needs

to be controlled quickly to
avoid ongoing problems.

Training your dog depends on a
good relationship built on

love and trust. It takes
time to build a working
partnership.

And the more time and patience
you have with your puppy from

day one, the more obedient
he'll be.
Dogs want to please.

I'm Kathy Santo for Iams with
Howdini, and I hope that you

found this helpful as you
welcome your new addition to
your family.

For more information about
puppy training, visit
iams.com/puppy.

title: How To Stop Puppy Biting: Training Puppies Not to Bite

comments.text:
These tips I'm about to share have been tested by me and I have finally 
taught my 3 month old pup to not bite humans & furniture. He understands 
using your teeth is strictly for eating food and playing with toys only. 
1) the ouch method - always exaggerate so the understand that humans are 
fragile. 
2) replace and redirect him to a chew toy 
3) muzzle him/her every time they bite. Shout muzzle so they know it's a 
punishment. 

Option 3 worked best for me. I got the muzzle for £2 off ebay and within 3 
days of using it he finally stopped biting. If however on the rare occasion 
he does try to bite or chew on my hand or furniture all I shout is 'muzzle' 
and he stops. 

Hope this helps! ﻿

comments.text:
Beware of buying a puppy from an Amish family.  We made the mistake and 
learned that dogs from such litters are treated as livestock rather than 
pets.  The animals are treated as a cash crop and sold to ignorant trusting 
city folk. The young dogs are not closely socialized with people and have 
little or no knowledge of lights, TV or radio.  Bringing these young dogs 
from that environment to a suburban home is a transition the dog we bought 
could not adapt.    ﻿

comments.text: everytime i pick up my puppy he start to bite me hard  what do i do?﻿
comments.author: Hayate Nakamura

comments.text:
He probably doesn't like being picked up. Distract him with a toy or 
something (unlike he's like my puppy) and when he doesn't bite, reward him.
comments.author: mintchoco tofu

comments.text: Did u not just see the video orrrrr??????
comments.author: Sean Vargas

comments.text:
Almost all puppies dislike getting picked up. Think about it, some giant 
bends over you and lifts you off the floor and clenches your ribs. It's 
frightening. But you can teach a puppy that it can be a good experience by 
giving hims treats for instance while you pick him up. It doesn't 
necessarily have to be treats. The most important thing is that you make 
being picked up seem really fun and not scary. And indeed a toy to divert 
the biting.
comments.author: Molly2471

comments.text:
You could try giving him a toy to chew on while you hold him. The best chew 
toy is an antler. My puppy's elk antler is her favorite chew. You can find 
them at petsmart for about $8 dollars each.

comments.text:
My puppy, now 3.5 months, has bitten hard since we got her from a dog 
rescue. She does not bite softly, she will try to bite hands, feet, ankles, 
calf muscles, and ears. I have tried to say "ouch" and redirect her 
attention to a toy. When I give her the toy she will still go for the hand 
rather than the toy. When playing in the backyard, even with a toy in her 
mouth, I can see her looking at my feet before she attacks. I have many 
marks on my hands and forearms from her biting. My husband and I have been 
trying to hold her to calm her down and it seems to be working than just 
redirecting. Is this ok discipline? ﻿

comments.author: It Is Faptime

comments.text:
A good way to discourage biting is by spraying your hands with something 
that tastes nasty. They make all sorts of non-toxic bad tasting sprays 
specifically to discourage dog biting and chewing (my parents used to spray 
it on my brother's hands to get him to stop biting his fingernails lol). It 
may take some getting used to, but I think that spraying your hands and 
shoes before handling the dog could help. It also sounds like you keep 
playing with the dog even when it bites hard by trying to redirect 
attention to a toy. Next time the dog bites hard, stop play altogether and 
ignore them for a while so the dog knows that nothing good comes from 
biting too hard.
* Also, try rubbing something safe and good tasting for dogs on the toys 
(something like peanut butter or turkey flavored baby food from Gerber). 
This will help teach the dog that the toys make much better tasting chew 
toys than human hands and feet.

comments.author: Jasmine Peach

comments.text:
(Sorry for replying so late) But the trick for me was to not keep playing 
with them after a hard bite. They learn that if they bite too hard, play 
stops. For many dogs, 'no play' is like a punishment. You could also try 
spraying your hands and shoes with Fooey or some other kind of bad-tasting 
non-toxic doggie spray to discourage biting during a play session. You 
should see some improvement every few times, but it does take patience and 
consistency on the owner's part.

comments.author: Berenice Losey

comments.text:
As a certified dog training - I do not recommend these methods. Allowing 
your puppy to mouth your hands can only further increase biting and in some 
cases when yelling ouch only further excites or startles your puppy. Best 
method is as soon as you get your puppy - teach not me bite toy. Basically 
a distraction method. Whenever your puppy bites place one of it toys in its 
mouth and praise. Stoke puppys head when he/she chews on the toy. For more 
aggressive biters, gently squish the upper jowl into the teeth and say 
gently no bite. They associate biting you - with biting themselves. ﻿
comments.author: Maslini

comments.text:
There is nothing wrong with a dog nibbling on your hands or any thing you 
allow it. The key word is allowing. You need to teach your dog when it is 
ok to bite and not to. That way they dont get bored only having chew toys 
and moving on to other things.

comments.text:
This is how I taught my puppies from biting.  I would also slap my hands 
when they chewed on things saying NO NO then have a toy where I could grab 
it, handing it to the puppy and praise praise praise them... I have never 
lost anything to any dog, shoes, purses, etc etc... using this maner, but 
keep up with it.  Why people allow their dog to rule them is beyond me.  A 
dog is like a child that never grows up, and we all know we must keep our 
children under control right? ﻿

comments.author: Emi Hayashi

comments.text:
Try yelping in a high pitched voice. Also, look away and cease eye contact. 
If you guys are playing, immediately stop and leave the room. Praise her 
when she stops and encourage low calorie treats to reinforce the good 
behaivor.

comments.author: aannamarie009

comments.text: My puppy gets more aggressive when we try to stop her biting.
comments.author: Chrissy Yi

comments.text:
good advice, so many "experts" with avideo camera are wayyyy off in 
training tips! once the puppy starts to learn that biting is a no-no, if 
you say "ouch" (has to be real, your dog can tell your tone of voice) if 
the biting continues, a tap (NOT hitting in anger, excessive force) 
reinforces that the biting is unacceptable behavior!! physical force in 
general is NOT an effective style of training!!
comments.author: Ann P

comments.text: what do you mean light touch on the soulder?
comments.author: Costas Dd

comments.text:
would it take a long time to teach your dog to stop biting because im 
getting a dog that bites and my parents said i have to teach her not to in 
2 weeks
comments.author: ♥Msp Productions♥

comments.text:
This isn't really good advice. Use positive reinforcement and not 
negative/reactive. So praise when the puppies do good and ignore/walk away 
from the bad. Don't react to the biting other than walking away or they'll 
think it's a fun game that you like too.
comments.author: BubblenessJay

comments.text:
I'm striving to be a dog behaviorist, and the yelling "ouch" technique only 
works on a certain number of dogs. Some puppies can perceive that as an 
invitation to keep biting. I had an eight week old beagle, and I found the 
light touch on the shoulder and becoming assertive (not mean or abusive, 
ASSERTIVE) worked a lot better. I didn't even need to use words to 
accomplish this. It didn't take a lot of time for him to get the message, 
and he seemed thankful for the structure and clear message! :)
comments.author: Sarah Weinstein

comments.text: THANK YOU!!! my puppy has stop biteing and mouthing..
comments.author: Edis Avila

comments.text:
Google and learn about crate training. It could help you. Also learn about 
dogs & how they think - the one thing she wants most in the world is you - 
you're her pack. If she gets mouthy and bites hard, *loudly* say No (or 
whatever word you want to use consistently), stand up and walk away. 
Completely ignore her. *completely*. Once she has settled (as she will 
eventually do), you can invite her to you & begin interacting again. Take 
control (assertively, not cruelly) of your relationship.
comments.author: littlekiwinelson

comments.text:
Hi I was wondering if I could get some help I have a 19 week old Kelpie/lab 
puppy. Her biting is becoming out of hand,we have used the ouch thing with 
her but now she sees it as a game. we also did holding her down to the 
ground getting her to stop but no its a game to her. At night time shes out 
of control since we can't put her out side cause of toads timeout we can't 
use any more since we have a rental house and she scratches the door. I was 
just wondering if you had some ideas. Thanks
comments.author: Nizer

comments.text:
Interesting, I used a different technique. Once he grew out of puppy stage, 
I introduced toys, and if he would start chewing on my hand or a finger, I 
would make a fist (inside his mouth) and lock his jaw open, thrusting fist 
closer to his throat. Chewing immediately stopped and in few short weeks he 
never chewed my hand, nor anyone else.
